text:
5 New Skincare Trends Thatâ€™ll Be Everywhere In 2026

2025 was a standout year forÂ skincare trends. In the spring,Â polynucleotides â€” DNA derived from salmonÂ or trout â€” took off, with experts using them in facial treatments to repair skinÂ andÂ boost hydration.Â By summer,Â LED face masksÂ were everywhere, praised for their ability to reduce acne and stimulateÂ collagen. Whether your main goal isÂ clearing up your skinÂ or investing inÂ skincare tech, here are the fiveÂ trendsÂ experts say will reign supreme in 2026 â€” andÂ thereâ€™sÂ something for everyone, no matter your skin type or budget.Â 

The next wave of Korean skincareÂ 

Mia Park, founder of New Yorkâ€“based K-beauty brandÂ Lazy Skincare, saysÂ weâ€™veÂ only seen the beginning of whatÂ Korean skincareÂ can achieve. â€œThe next wave of innovation is alreadyÂ emergingÂ as Korean labs push boundaries in texture science, botanicals, and multifunctional formulas,â€ says Park.Â Lazyâ€™sÂ Double DutyÂ â€” a serum-moisturizerÂ duoÂ â€” is an example of how brands are combining effective plant-based ingredients (think red camellia andÂ bakuchiol to target uneven skin tone, and silver ear mushroom to boost moisture) with skin-strengthening, fast-healing peptides and oil-controlling niacinamide.Â Â 

K-beauty treatments are set to make their way into skincare clinics, too. Local Dynamic Micro-Massage, or LDM, utilizes dual-frequency ultrasound to stimulate collagen and elastin â€” key proteins that provide skin with structure and strength. A 20-minute session can also reduce inflammation and support the skin barrier, the outermost layer that locks in moisture andÂ keeps outÂ bacteria. LDM should always be performed by a qualified dermatologist or esthetician.Â 

Slow-release skincareÂ 

IfÂ youâ€™veÂ fallen into the â€œmore is moreâ€ trap â€” overloading your skin withÂ high concentrations of retinoids, exfoliating acids, andÂ antioxidants like vitamin CÂ â€”Â advanced facialistÂ MariamÂ AbbasÂ says thatÂ the slow-release skincare trendÂ is for you.Â She points out that many brands are now â€œencapsulatingâ€ their formulas, wrapping potent ingredients in tiny moisturizing capsules for controlled release. They reach the skin a little more slowly but still deliver results â€” without irritation.Â 

TakeÂ TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s new Starter Retinol Serum, which features encapsulated retinol. The encapsulated ingredient acts like a cushion, targeting uneven skin tone, texture, and fine lines while minimizing the risk of sore, sensitive, dry, or flaky skin. IfÂ youâ€™reÂ a seasoned retinoid user, tryÂ theÂ brandâ€™sÂ Advanced 0.2% Retinal Serum.Â Not to be confused withÂ retinol,Â retinalÂ works fasterÂ because it requires fewer steps to convert into retinoic acid on theÂ skin â€”Â the active ingredient thatÂ actually getsÂ to work.Â The retinal in this product is also encapsulated, which helps make dry, sensitive skin much less of a concern.Â 

If you prefer exfoliating acids, opt for a leave-on formula that works gradually, rather than a high-strength flash mask that can leave skin feeling parched. Try Timeline Skincareâ€™s Mito-Biotic Resurfacing Exfoliator, which uses a balanced trifecta of acids â€” including gentle salicylic, lactic, and mandelic acids â€” to help prevent breakouts while improving skin texture and tone.

Skin wellbeingÂ 

â€œA cultural shift isÂ underway,Â and living well is replacing the need to appear busy,â€ says Park, adding, â€œThis mindset is reshaping beauty,â€Â specifically, skincare. Bloomberg recently proclaimed that â€œwellness is the new nightlife,â€ Park points out, and she says that in 2026, the skincare products that will succeed are those that support â€œcalm, recovery, and low-stress routines.â€Â Â 

Lazyâ€™sÂ Double Duty Serum Moisturizer DuoÂ features squalane, glycerin, hyaluronic acid, and peptides to hydrate, moisturize, and support the skinâ€™s natural healing response. Skincare packed with vitamins is anotherÂ optionÂ â€” likeÂ Dermalogica Biolumin-C Night Restore Serum with Pro-Vitamin D Complex, which brightens and strengthens the skin barrier overnight.Â TheÂ InkeyÂ Listâ€™s Vitamin B, C, and E MoisturizerÂ helpsÂ control excess oil, shields against environmental aggressors such as pollution, and provides deep hydrationÂ in one go.Â 

Weâ€™ll also see more products spotlighting matcha and green tea as hero ingredients, helping to protect skin from urban stressors thanks to their antioxidant properties. Try Timeline Skincare Mito-Biotic Firming Serum, infused with green tea, or TirTir Matcha Calming Cream to help quell redness. Park makes a great point: â€œYouÂ canâ€™tÂ out-serumÂ an exhausted nervous system, but beauty productsÂ that make space for rest is the future.â€Â 

Underspending on the basicsÂ 

DermatologistÂ Dr. OpheliaÂ VeraitchÂ has noticed that many patients assume the more expensive a product, the better the results. â€œThatâ€™s rarely true,â€ she says. In fact, she recommends sticking to the basics for cleansers and moisturizers. There are plenty of excellent, affordable options for all skin types, includingÂ The Ordinary Glucoside Foaming Cleanser,Â CeraVe Hydrating Facial Cleanser, andÂ ByomaÂ Blemish Clearing Creamy Cleanser.Â Â 

When it comes to moisturizers, simple is often best, especially ifÂ youâ€™reÂ layering serums with active ingredients like retinol, vitamin C, or exfoliating acids. Our favorites includeÂ Neutrogena Hydro Boost Water Gel,Â e.l.f. Holy Hydration Moisturizer, andÂ Cetaphil Daily Hydrating Lotion.Â 

Dr.Â VeraitchÂ recommends investing in high-quality active ingredients suited to your skin type and concerns, for example, niacinamide for oily or acne-prone skin, or hyaluronic acid for dry, dehydrated skin, along with a reliable, high-factor broad-spectrum sunscreen. â€œThis mattersÂ far more thanÂ price,â€ she says.Â 

Minimalism is the new luxuryÂ 

â€œIn 2026, the most desirable routines wonâ€™t be the longest,â€ says Park, â€œtheyâ€™ll be the smartest.â€ With budgets tightening and dermatologists noting that multi-step skincare routines can sometimes be counterproductive, Park predictsÂ weâ€™llÂ favor fewer products, clearer choices, and formulas that truly multitask.Â 

Think moisturizers packed with active ingredients that can replace toners and serums. R29 recommendsÂ Dr. Idriss Major Fade Active Seal Moisturizer, which features brightening vitamin CÂ andÂ eliminatesÂ the need for a dedicated serum.Â Also worth trying areÂ MuradÂ SuperactiveÂ Mattifying Oil + Pore Control Moisturizer SPF 50, a high-factor SPF with oil-reducing niacinamide, andÂ ByomaÂ Blemish Acne Control Moisturizer, which uses salicylic acid to prevent new breakouts while providing deep hydration.Â 

Park says that minimalismÂ isnâ€™tÂ about doing less for yourÂ skin.Â â€œItâ€™s about guiltlessly skipping what doesnâ€™t matter and prioritizing what does.â€Â Â

In a year that felt endlessly chaotic and packed with horrific headlines, TV stepped up as our most reliable emotional support system. 2025 gave us shows that made us scream-text the group chat, cancel plans for just one more episode, and rethink everything from love, to friendship, to what counts as a satisfying finale. From series that demanded our full attention to reality TV that went from chaotic to comforting to culturally essential, weâ€™re honoring the full spectrum of what great TV looks like. If it sparked a debate, delivered a meme, or made us feel something unexpectedly real, it earned its spot.Â 

The PittÂ 

For some reason, I was never into Greyâ€™s Anatomy, Scrubs, ER, or any of the popular hospital dramas even during their streaming resurgences. But after everyone from family to strangers recommended watching The Pitt (starring and executive-produced by ERâ€™s very own Noah Wyle) and being bombarded with interviews of Wylie talking about how his nurse mom influenced the storyline for more accurate depictions of what itâ€™s actually like to work in a hospital, I finally gave in. And wow, was I stunned.Â 

Each of the 15 episodes represent one hour of a consecutive 15-hour emergency room shift. Itâ€™s fast-paced and chaotic but has moments of levity, and manages to dive deep into each of the doctors, nurses, and residentsâ€™ eccentricities and back stories. I found myself instantly hooked and invested into the core doctors and incoming patients, no matter how likeable, unlikeable, long, or short their storylines were. The heavy, high-strung, high-stakes series is a must-watch. But to warn you, it is certainly not a show to wind down to after a hectic day! â€“ Victoria Montalti, Senior Fashion Writer

Love Island USA Season 7Â 

When an Irish friend first introduced me to Love Island via the showâ€™s original UK iteration in 2022, I was equally horrified and intrigued by the sheer logistics of it all. The idea of committing to a show that airs a new episode six nights a week for two and a half months straight â€” featuring a revolving door of 30-or-so contestants and their constantly recalibrating romances â€” was a lot to wrap my head around. But, as someone who deeply appreciates lowbrow reality TV both as a form of sociological fieldwork and, obviously, for pure eye candy, I was up for the task.Â 

This year, Love Island USA season 7 brought the country together in ways seldom seen before, becoming a full-blown cultural phenomenon that revived the glory days of participatory reality TV. My roommate and I grew closer as we watched and voted together each night (and shrieked in horror at the showâ€™s absolutely unhinged challenges). My colleagues and I raced to our Slack channels each morning to share hot takes. Even in New York City, where people famously mind their business, Iâ€™d find myself talking about the show with a friend on the street or subway, only to have strangers jump in mid-conversation to share their opinions.

What ultimately made season 7 feel like a classic was (most of) the castâ€™s emotional vulnerability. It gave us a heroâ€™s arc in Amaya Papaya (nÃ©e Espinal), who brought a rare level of authenticity and sensitivity to reality TV, a friends-to-star-crossed-lovers romance in Olandria and Nic, healthy debates about what it really means to be â€œa girls girl,â€ and enough memes to last a lifetime (Mamacita, anyone?). â€“ Lia Tabackman, Senior Social Media ManagerÂ 

Heated Rivalry

Iâ€™m going to start with a quote from Heated Rilvarlyâ€™s creator, writer and showrunner, Jacob Tierney: â€œPutting queer sex on the screen in a celebratory and sexy way is not common at allâ€¦ people were clearly craving that kind of thing,â€ Tierney told The Ankler. â€œThey wanted to see sexually alive, queer people in a way that we kind of self-censor and donâ€™t always do. I donâ€™t think the show is popular despite the horniness; I think itâ€™s popular because of the horniness.â€ Exactly. Recently, TV and film have been oddly sexless, seemingly scared to show erotism on screen and convinced audiences donâ€™t want to see pretty people kissing. I beg to differ.

Iâ€™ve been pushing the horny TV agenda for years and finally, here comes a show to match my freak. But itâ€™s not just about the beautifully tender, explicit, real, and hot sex scenes, Heated Rivalry contains some of the most heartfelt and romantic storytelling Iâ€™ve ever seen on TV. And thatâ€™s only after five episodes! I am already unhealthily obsessed with this show and I canâ€™t wait for more. As someone who belongs to multiple romance book clubs, Iâ€™m so happy that a show based on a romance novel (written by Rachel Reid) is getting the love it deserves. Plus, a show about gay hockey players airing in 2025 â€” when male athletes would still face so much prejudice, homophobia, and an extremely hard time if they came out IRL â€” is not only bold and brave, itâ€™s revolutionary. â€“ Kathleen Newman-Bremang, Senior Content Director, EntertainmentÂ 

The Summer I Turned Pretty Season 3Â 

I admittedly didnâ€™t watch much TV this year, but there was one show that had me in a chokehold: Season 3 of The Summer I Turned Pretty. To be honest, I didnâ€™t particularly enjoy this season. As Team Jeremiah (Gavin Casalegno), a lot of it was insufferable, mostly because Conrad (Christopher Briney) remains an unbearable character to watch. Heâ€™s going to talk down to Belly (Lola Tung) and make her feel crazy for years AND do his brother like that, and they still want me to believe heâ€™s not the villain in this show? (You ainâ€™t gaslighting me, Connie Baby!). I also couldnâ€™t stand the way the writers seemed determined to assassinate Jeremiahâ€™s character. Still, to paraphrase a Taylor Swift lyric, Jenny Han really puts narcotics into all of her episodes, because no matter how much I wanted to look away, I just couldnâ€™t. â€“ Raquel Reichard, Director of Somos

The Hunting WivesÂ 

When I first started The Hunting Wives, I wasnâ€™t prepared for what I signed up for. I assumed I would be watching a show about wives getting back at their cheating husbands. I was right, but also so wrong. I spent most of the time being mad at the main character Sophie (Brittany Snow), literally rolling my eyes at the screen at her antics. That said, I will be back for Season 2. â€“ Dawnie Jefferson Production & Editorial Coordinator

The Secret Lives of Mormon WivesÂ 

The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives was my favorite TV show of 2025 because it didnâ€™t just understand the assignment, it overdelivered. TWO seasons in one year? Bravo could never. By breaking the fourth wall and letting the off-screen drama (hello, Fruity Pebbles) bleed into the show, it captured the same raw magic as early Vanderpump Rules seasons, back when the cast wanted fame at any cost and didnâ€™t know, or care, to hold anything back.

Season 3 was filmed before Season 2 even premiered, giving us something almost unheard of in reality TV: reunions being taped, press tours unfolding, and cast dynamics shifting in real time as they reacted to public opinion. The timeline was messy, but for reality fans, that level of transparency was all weâ€™ve ever wanted.

We watched marriages implode, secret affairs surface, and learned way too much about their sex lives. Not every storyline worked (the sexual assault allegations were uncomfortable and difficult to watch), but the drama was balanced by something real: raw, unprocessed trauma shared in a way that genuinely resonated.

Taylor Frankie Paul becoming the Bachelorette only cemented the showâ€™s chokehold on pop culture, while Whitney Leavitt started the year as the ultimate villain and ended it as the main character of Dancing with the Stars and getting cast as Roxie Hart on Broadway. The range! And all of this unfolded in the hyper-specific, endlessly fascinating playground of Swig sodas, Utah curls, and Mormon cultureâ€”proof that you donâ€™t need alcohol for reality TV gold. â€“ Taylor Loren, Social StrategistÂ 

ForeverÂ 

Mara Brock Akilâ€™s Forever feels like it was made specifically for me â€” for the 16 year old version of me who needed to see herself, who longed for stories that reflected Black girlhood and humanity and the complexity of being a Black kid in a white space â€” and thatâ€™s only partially why I loved it so much. For the teenager in me who was messily figuring out her sexuality, Keisha and Justin would have been my fictional best friends. For the thirty-redacted grownup who needed an escape and just loves romance, Forever delivered in-depth, nuanced explorations of how sex can be absolutely everything and sometimes nothing at all.

Listen, Iâ€™m too grown to believe that representation will save us, but it does matter. And what this show represents (Black kids falling in love and finding themselves) is portrayed in such a caring, thoughtful way that as you fall in love with Keisha and Justin, as a Black person, you canâ€™t help but love yourself more. This show loves us. It finds beauty in Blackness, in the nuances and flaws of youth. It lets Keisha be complicated and messy and Justin be introspective and vulnerable; two things that Black girls and boys arenâ€™t typically allowed to be on TV. This show is my wildest dreams come true. Itâ€™s the show I wish I had when I was a teenager and Iâ€™m so grateful that Black teens get this show now. â€“ Kathleen Newman-Bremang, Senior Content Director, EntertainmentÂ 

Abbott Elementary Season 5

Abbott Elementary is my comfort show when I want to just laugh and not have to think. I can usually jump into any episode in the season or binge several of the 22-minute episodes and still understand whatâ€™s happening. In the same style as cult-favorite comedies like The Office and Parks & Rec, this workplace â€œmockumentaryâ€ follows the staff of a Philadelphia elementary school and captures all the drama and antics youâ€™d expect to happen during everyday lifeâ€”in and out of school. The show is currently in the middle of season five and we see teachers Janine and Gregoryâ€™s relationship continue to develop. A few of the recent episodes have taken the setting out of the school, but my favorites are usually when the teachers and staff, especially Principal Ava Coleman and teacher Ms. Melissa Schementti, are just trying to get through the school day. For me, itâ€™s easy sitcom watching. â€“ Lisa Dionisio, Newsletter Director

The Beast In Me

If I were putting together a dream team of prestige TV, I would immediately call up Claire Danes and Matthew Rhys for my starting five. Danes proved in Homeland, and throughout her storied career, that she can do a chin quiver like no other, and that there is no emotion she canâ€™t convey through the careful crumpling of her face. And Rhys, along with his real-life wife Keri Russell, showed on The Americans that he can make even the most ethically-questionable character someone you canâ€™t help but be intrigued by. In The Beast In Me, these two heavyweights come together for some of the best TV of the year.Â 

Both Danes and Rhys are so compelling in The Beast In Me, you wonâ€™t be able to look away for all eight episodes. Danes brings her signature emotional precision, playing every flicker of doubt and defiance like a controlled burn, while Rhys does what he does best: make moral ambiguity feel devastatingly human. Together, they create a push-pull dynamic thatâ€™s an unsettling dissertation on good versus evil and what happens when the lines between the two start to blue. Their chemistry isnâ€™t flashy; itâ€™s claustrophobic, simmering, and kind that makes silence feel louder than dialogue and turns every shared glance into a threat. Itâ€™s prestige acting without the self-importance, and itâ€™s exactly why the show gets under your skin and stays there. â€“ Kathleen Newman-Bremang, Senior Content Director, EntertainmentÂ 

The Buccanneers Season 2

This past summer, I was indulging in some YA love-triangle drama and watching TSITP and The Buccaneers Season 2 on Apple TV. If youâ€™re not familiar with The Buccaneers, itâ€™s a period drama set in 1870s England following five gorgeous American women trying to find titled husbands and independence. Season 2 tries to resolve a love triangle set up in Season 1 between Nan, Guy, and Theo. New affairs and betrayals between the couples develop, and itâ€™s guilty-pleasure watching, especially for period romance fans. Spoiler warning: season two ends in another cliffhanger but the showâ€™s already been greenlit for a season three. â€“ Lisa Dionisio, Newsletter Director

The Z SuiteÂ 

I know Tubi gets a bad rep for its content, but do NOT sleep on them. I loved everything about the Z Suite! The characters were fun. The plots were full of shenanigans. It fueled the Gen Z vs. Millennial fire in a way that leaves you with the idea, â€œwe are more alike than differentâ€. It had a sense of true comedic whimsy, while many other shows are just too serious. I am unsure if it will be renewed for another season, but I sure hope so! â€“ Dawnie Jefferson Production & Editorial Coordinator

ParadiseÂ 

Paradise is a mystery series starring Emmy winner Sterling K. Brown about a secret service agent whose president is murdered and itâ€™s so good, it got renewed for a second season halfway into its first. So Iâ€™m just going to quote myself from March writing about Paradise just after it was renewed: â€œWeâ€™re in an age where a show with a Black lead gets written off by online trolls as â€˜too wokeâ€™ or full of â€˜DEI hiresâ€™ and anything that makes us feel our feelings gets denigrated as â€˜silly.â€™ But the absurdity and sincerity of Paradise is its strength. And its hero? A Black man, the descendent of a Tuskegee airman and Black pilot, who took a bullet for the president, may feel a bit too nationalistic for the current moment, but it also harkens back to a time when that guy was the hero everyone welcomed, and the one TV wanted. Right now, Sterling K. Brown as Xavier Collins is the hero we need.â€ â€“ Kathleen Newman-Bremang, Senior Content Director, EntertainmentÂ 

Ghosts

This year marked Season 4 and 5 of Ghosts, and it is consistently one of my favorite comfort watches. I literally force anyone who comes to my house to watch it with me. Season 4 gave the characters so much more backstory. Season 5 adds to that. If you want a good, wholesome chuckle, you should definitely watch this show. â€“ Dawnie Jefferson Production & Editorial Coordinator

title: Vanilla Fragrances Need a Rebrand (Respectfully) & This New Line Is The Scentâ€™s Savior
text:
Vanilla Fragrances Need a Rebrand (Respectfully) & This New Line Is The Scentâ€™s Savior

Itâ€™s 2010. Iâ€™m 13 years old and Iâ€™m on my way to what I know will be one of the craziest nights of my life: The Justin Bieber My World 2.0 Tour. As I crank my hair straightener up way too high (RIP to my ends), I pause mid-section and wonder: What am I missing? What would truly make Justin fall in love with me? And then it hits me: my vanilla cupcake perfume from Claireâ€™s.

The perfume is aggressively sugary and smells like straight icing. All my mom could hear from downstairs was sksksksksks as I drowned myself in it, fully convinced that if Justin couldnâ€™t see me from the stage, he would at least smell me. And well, not to spoil the ending, butâ€¦ he did not fall in love with me that night. Congrats, Hailey!

What did happen, though, was far more consequential: that was the night I fell in love with gourmand fragrances, specifically, vanilla. I never cared what brand it was, as long as the bottle starts with buttery, whipped, or sugar, I was in.

Life was going great until one day, a coworker casually mentions that my favorite fragrance reminds her of what it smells like to be a child. Suddenly, I was overthinking everything. Was I still that 13-year-old hoping to be noticed by JB, or did my signature scent simply need a rebrand?

Turns out, it was both.

When I heard that Soap & Glory dropped a brand-new, mood-boosting fragrance line, I was intrigued. It covers pretty much every palette. Thereâ€™s Tropical Sunrise with pineapple and coconut, Orchid Bliss with orchid and sandalwood, Radiant Rose with florals and bergamot, Watermelon Spritz for something bright and juicy, and of course Vanilla-licious with warm caramel and vanilla notes. With a set with this much range, itâ€™s perfect for mixing and matching. And with each fragrance under $20, it felt like the perfect chance to find my signature scent and actually play around with layering.

Since I hadnâ€™t elevated my fragrance in nearly 20 years, I tapped the internetâ€™s favorite fragrance guru, Paul Fino, for advice on how to layer scents and whether I can keep being a vanilla girl at my big age.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Unbothered: So talk to me about vanilla. Do you think itâ€™s having a moment right now? And do you think itâ€™s one of those scents that transcends seasons, like a year-round thing?

Paul Fino: Yeah, for sure. Vanilla is year-round for me because there are so many vanilla-adjacent scents. You can find vanillas that lean super creamy, more floral, or even more powdery. That said, vanilla is definitely most popular in fall and winter. People love warm gourmands in colder months, and in summer they usually want something more tropical, fruity, or fresh. But vanilla is not going anywhere. Itâ€™s had its moment and itâ€™s become one of those things that just sticks around.

My coworker said vanilla is childish. So when you see something like Vanilla-licious, which feels more grown and sexy but still has that inner-child sweetness, how do you elevate it? How do you layer it so you donâ€™t smell like cupcake perfume from Limited Too?

PF: I 100% get that. A lot of gourmand vanillas can lean artificial or very young. When people say they want a â€œmatureâ€ vanilla, I get it, but â€œmatureâ€ doesnâ€™t mean grandma. It can mean deeper, sexier, more attractive. One of my favorite ways to elevate Vanilla-licious is pairing it with Radiant Rose. Radiant Rose is basically their iconic signature scent, but repackaged and made a little newer and fresher. Rose is romantic, and it deepens the vanilla. The musk in both helps them blend really beautifully. That vanilla-rose combination is gorgeous.

I feel like layering fragrance is like cooking. You wouldnâ€™t put mustard and jelly together. So how do you know what works? Whatâ€™s the science of scent layering, especially for someone new who wants to smell unique but still wearable?

PF: Itâ€™s all about understanding notes and scent families. I can usually predict how something will smell based on the notes and how many fragrances Iâ€™ve experienced, but a simple rule is to keep things in similar scent profiles if you want to play it safe. Sweets with sweets, gourmands with gourmands. For example, vanilla with pineapple and coconut makes sense because itâ€™s tropical sweet. Vanilla and coconut always work together, so Vanilla-licious with Tropical Sunrise is an easy layering combo.

What about combinations that are risky?

PF: Sometimes mixing two different ends of the spectrum can clash, but sometimes a clash is exactly what makes it interesting. Thatâ€™s how you get people to ask, â€œWhat are you wearing?â€ Also, fragrance wears differently on everyone, so experimentation matters.

Are these meant to be layered only with each other, or can you layer them with perfumes too?

PF: You can absolutely layer these with perfumes. Theyâ€™re body mists, but they have really good projection and longevity, especially for the price point. Theyâ€™re great as base layers.

Do you have a method for layering? Like an order you follow?

PF:Yes. I do heaviest to lightest. I start with my deepest scent first, like a heavy wood or musk, then layer lighter scents on top. Itâ€™s kind of like how fragrance is built, with base notes, heart notes, and top notes.

If someone just wants one scent from the line for self-care, like a shower that makes you feel calm and relaxed, which one is it?

PF: Orchid Bliss. Hands down. If you want truly relaxing and calming, Orchid Bliss is the one. Itâ€™s slightly sweet, it has sandalwood, and there are also notes like vanilla and pistachio in there, but they feel more subtle and deeper in the background. Itâ€™s like a spa in a bottle.

Why not Vanilla-licious for calm?

PF: Vanilla makes me feel confident. Like, super confident. Orchid Bliss gives more calm spa-night energy. If youâ€™re tired, overworked, and want the most relaxing shower, Iâ€™d do scrub, wash, body butter, and spray in Orchid Bliss, then top it with your favorite perfume if you want extra oomph.

DashDividers_1_500x100

After talking to Paul, I realized it was never really about retiring vanilla. It was about wearing it with intention. It was about keeping the sweetness but adding depth. Itâ€™s time to let my inner 13-year-old have her moment, while my grown self makes my scent feel polished. So yes, Iâ€™m still a vanilla girl. Iâ€™m just a vanilla girl with range now.
